name: The Ricky Gervais Guide to: Society

transcript.content: [~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]

But you seem to be doing a lot of leafleting. That seems to be-- your entire governance seems to be guided by popping leaflets through doors. And I get a lot of leaflets, so I'm presuming the rest of the country does, and it's not always working. So maybe sometimes you've got to instigate something to be a little bit more strong-minded than fucking leaflets, my friend.
Yeah.
You've got to make a couple of laws, you've got to stand up...
Also, this thing that every individual can go, "How would I want to be treated? Um, well, I'd want someone to throw cake at me."
Yeah.
Because I'm a greedy bastard.
I would want someone to steal my telly.
I'd probably start on the way you look.
Right, go on.
I'd just- I'd just say, "Right, you know, make an effort. Tidy up your house." And I'd have some sort of, um...
"I'm poor"
Doesn't matter, doesn't matter. You can still tidy up, love.
"Can we get better houses then? 'Cause..."
Well look after the one that we've let you. Get rid of that old mattress that's in your garden there.
Ricky laughs
Clean the windows. And then we might give you a nicer one. At the moment, you don't deserve anything nicer. And that's what I'm saying. You've got to be honest with these people. Wake 'em up!
I like that.
Sure, you've got to be honest with them, you've got to wake them up. Through a heavy leafleting campaign.
[Laughing] Yeah, yeah!
But do you see the problem with some of what you're saying, Karl, is that it's very hard to, uh, to enforce that--
Yeah.
--in law because it seems unjust and unfair. You can't really start legislating against people's looks or whether they want--
I don't mean--
I mean, you have to keep your house tidy? I mean, who decides how tidy it has to be? The tidy police? I mean, that's a strange--

Yeah. Well, hold on, though. I, um, I like wearing sort of these, these, um, denims. It expresses who I am. And I like wearing a beard because I just think it's natural. I don't like, really like shaving. And yeah, I like this sort of smell. I like this smell of B.O. That's who I am as a person. So I don't-- how can you impose that on me just to be part of the society? Who are you to infringe my rights as an individual?
What do you want out of life?

Well, no, I think-- I'd just like to say I don't, I don't want to conform. I don't want to just shave and wear a suit. And, you know, I keep myself to myself. And I like to, uh, just grow a beard, uh, and eat porridge with my hands. I'm not hurting anyone, so I don't know why I have to conform to that society.
Well, there's nothing I can do for you. You're... yeah, wasting me time, really.
Although I do feel ill. I need to go to hospital now. Um, so I'm going to go to hospital now. So uh, I'm going to go to hospital now if that's alright? Is there- is there- is there care for me?
Well, what's up with you?
I've got diseases from, like, eating with me hands and there's things growing in me beard.
Right.
Um, so will you just-- will you clean it up for me now?
No, 'cause it's all been brought on yourself.
Well, no, but that's irrelevant. A lot of people bring things on themselves, but you can't just, like, ignore them because it's [mumbling] society...
How do they learn then?
I don't know why I'm being punished for being stupid.
How do they learn then?
Well, I've got--
I don't understand why I've got to worry about you. We've got proper ill people.
Well, there--
You had a kid whinging at me this morning because his dad was a mong.
Ricky laughs.
Obviously, in China you can only have, uh, one child, can't you? Is that something you feel we should bring in here?
Uh, yeah, I think we, we've gotta uh, I don't know about one kid. I'd just sort of concentrate on who can have a kid.
Okay.
'Cause if I was to, y'know-- if someone's got a load of money and they're good at looking after kids, let Madonna have as many as she wants.
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
What would you do?
Umm, am I far from where I'm getting off?

So once again, you can't just nip out at the next stop so you can wash your hands of the whole affair. No, you're on that bus. You've still got a number of stops. You live further away than Rosa does because you've got a lovely big house where obviously she doesn't have a lovely place, she can't afford it. So you've got to stay on that bus. You've seen this now. You've seen this bus driver demanding that she gets up, gives up that seat. Maybe she's giving up that seat for you. Maybe you've got on that bus as a privileged white man and she refuses to get up on your behalf.
Uhh, I'd probably go, "It's all right, I'm standing, I'm all right."
But why would you say that? Because you're thinking of the modern day Karl. You're not thinking of the man from the 1950s.

Well, the thing is well, we don't have to go back in time, we can go to a country now where you'd see an injustice, where you were outnumbered by the law of the land. What if Suzanne wasn't allowed to sit with you on buses? What if now a law came in that women were second class citizens and she can't come with you? Wouldn't you go, "no, fuck that. She's sitting with me."

I'd say, "we're only going around the block. We've been to the shopping center. We'll be only 15 minutes. Can you take that bag with you because there's no one sat next to you down there? I'm a bit crammed in up here. There's more blokes on the bus. See ya in a minute." It's not a big issue. I've done it on the train. Where I've booked tickets and they've ended up being different tickets and I've gone, "I'll see you in an hour and a half. I've got an ipod."
But that's luck. That's luck. That's circumstance. One is policy. Surely you can see the difference between a principle and a bit of luck.

Uhm, but it's what you get used to, at the end of the day. I mean, I'm not walking past them, slapping them on the back of the head. I'm getting on. And it's just that's where they sit. That's where we sit. Like men and women going into a separate toilet.
Karl, let's put this to... I mean, obviously, this is too much for your head to... You're on a bus, right? And there's a few white people and they're...
I'm the driver?
And they're being racist to a black kid.
Right, I'd go, If I'm driving, I'd go, "Listen Lads, stop that, will ya?"
If you're going to be racist, can you get off at the next stop and do it there?
"We've all had a tough day. It's the end of the day, we just all want to go home. We've all been working. Uhh, he's not in your way. He's sat in his own seat. Sit back. Calm down. Had enough.
But what if they said, no, we usually sit there. We want that seat. Would you think the black kid's a troublemaker? Would you go, "Come on, just move mate it'd be peaceful."
I'd go, "What do you want to do? Do you want to move so this is calmed down?"
No, no, no, no you shouldn't say that. It doesn't matter if he wants to move or not. It's his right not to move.
"Do what you want, then. If you want to stay there and fight your own corner."
No! He wants to stay there, surely you want to be on the side of right?
"I'm just doing my job here. I'm sat driving a bus, I'm driving a bus for 30 quid a week here and I'm getting a load of grief...
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
But now it's just walking over the little medal.
So, Suzanne, we, y'know, we leave it for a bit.
Leave it - what do you say -
About half an hour. Left it for half an hour.
What did Suzanne want to do? She wanted to interfere, did she? What did she want to do? Just sort of like -
She just sort of said 'Leave it, stop messing with it. It's probably a little bit knocked out. A little bit stunned.'
Sure, let's get on with our lives, she said.
So, I put the leaf on it.
You put on too much Fairy Liquid. Why didn't you use a dishwasher?
So, we go off, and half an hour later I get back in, and I said 'I'm gonna go and see the cricket.'
Where'd you go? Where'd you go?
Just for a walk.

But, hold on. Why didn't you put the dishes in the dishwasher and go for a walk? I don't understand. So, now you're - now there's a dishwasher sitting there bone idle. You're washing up when you could be walking - and then you're still walking.
It's a good job I didn't go for a walk, though, wasn't it? Cause how would that have turned out?
That fight?
I don't know.
There just would've been a pool of blood on your back door.
So I've been out, back in. Had a look. Cricket's still there. Noticed one of its legs - gone.
Aw.
Don't know if the wasp did that. Or the tea towel flick.
Or it was already disabled and that's why the wasp thought, 'this is an easy one'. What if the wasp was helping it?
It wasn't, though, honestly.
But what if it was going, 'Because we're such friends and humans don't understand us, and anyone who interferes definitely don't understand us. Right. He's not an entomologist.'
This is when I got the computer out.
Right.
Had a look, and it's a - what's it called?
Brilliant.
I can't remember. What happened is, the wasp apparently does this a lot, and it stings them in the head.
Not this particular - there wasn't a little profile of this particular wasp, on a kind of police website.
Yeah.
It's just an incident that happens a lot between wasps and crickets.
Right.
So it's stung it in the head. And what happens is - it's that whole thing that we've talked about before, where it lays an egg.
Right.
So I was sort of having a look, seeing if I could see any sort of holes in his head. And it just kept sort of moving its one leg, like 'Aw, I can't handle this'.
What do you mean, moving its one leg?
It was sort of just moving its one leg quite slowly, like it's just come out an operation.
But it's only got one leg. It lost one leg you said.
It's lost one.
Yeah. It's moving five legs slowly.
No, it's just this one big one.
He's got one big leg?
One big leg at the back, now. It's usually got two that uses to jump.
Oh, I see. So uh, okay. Right.
So now it's only got one. It's sort of like 'Uh' it looks groggy.
Is it not a grasshopper if it's jump - is it not - what colour was it?
Sort of, uh, beige.
Oh, it's probably a cricket. Yeah.
So, anyway...
Important.
So, you were worried that crickets aren't aware of the dangers of wasps? You did a bit of leafleting amongst the cricket community?

I just had a look online and saw that, oh, it's a popular thing that happens. It's like a bit of a mugging. It said you can leave them for about half an hour, they normally come round and they don't know they've had an egg put in their head.
There's no way it said, 'leave them for half an hour and they come round and don't know they've had an egg put in their head'. There's no way it said that.
It said they're normally stunned for about half hour.
Have you had an egg put in your head?
Fucking ostrich egg by the look of it.
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
No you didn't.
I did, honestly. Honest to God on me mam's life. I said: 'Why, was it shut?' She said-
Hold on, why did you butt in?
Why did you get involved?
She wasn't even talking to you.
Honestly, I know, it's really, really weird. It's really weird.
But did you have to shout across the dentist's waiting room? Or were you stood next to her?

No no it's was just- it's a small waiting room you see. You got the stairs, you go in, you got about four chairs and then this old desk, and I get on with the woman behind the counter and I always sit close to it and it was just me there and I was talking to her about going to Corfu or something, she comes in sweating like some bison up the stairs.
Ricky Laughs

-and she's there. And because she was showing off, I was like, well, you should have done it a long time ago. I think she annoyed me that she wanted some sort of pat on her- on her big hefty fat back that she hadn't bothered having a doughnut that day. Now, maybe it's the inner me that just came out, because I remember saying it and actually getting home and saying to Suzanne, 'ohh I said this, and I didn't even think- I don't know where it came from.'

I know what you mean though. Sometimes- Sometimes you want to go round with people and they're going [whining sounds]  you want to put them down. You wanna go 'I'm stopping helping you, because you're going to go straight back to that and do this, that. I know you've had a lot- just inject them in the head. Absolutely pointless. Get rid of it. Yeah, I know what you mean. But talking about social etiquette, I was uh flying to Edinburgh and I was with Matt, my assistant, and um there was a bloke on a mobile phone across the way. He was going, 'Yeah, I'm just going to get on a plane now.' And he kept talking that loudly to people, right. And I was fuming. Then he stopped and made another call and I was giving him dirty looks and Matt was going 'no sit down, sit down.' And then he was going, 'Hiya, in the airport!' And I shouted, 'he's in the airport!' He didn't notice. I was shouting over, I was fuming and fuming. And Matt was just getting so embarrassed.
But they don't see it, though.

And people were looking at me like I was the mental case, but it was so fucking loud. And I moved through to another place, but I wanted to get someone. I wanted it to be policed. I wanted to go, Right, there's a cunt over there, swigging beer, thinks he's a fucking Gordon Gecko player and he's not. He's some cunt who's got his first mobile phone. Right? You know what I mean? That is infringing. That is like- That's like passive smoking to me.
Yeah.
It annoys me when you hear these awful middle class parents talking to their kid loud enough to let everyone know what their kid knows. Do you know what I mean?
Yeah.

They bring up conversations because they're showing off about the kid: 'Um, Toby, what's that you were saying earlier about you preferred Beethoven to-?' Right, okay, if that kid talks about Beethoven and Chopin, right... Do you know what I mean, though? It's like people showing off thinking that the world is interested in everything they fucking say. Th-that thing about everyone's got access, which is fine, but it's those fat fucking morons on Docusopes that go, 'I speak as I fucking think,' you useless fucking blob of shit.
Yes. Have an education, research, think, discuss, then offer your opinion.
And stop-
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
